data.value: Spectrograms can be used as a way of visualizing the change of a nonstationary signal's frequency content over time.

An appropriate amount of overlap will depend on the choice of window and on your requirements. In contrast to welch's method, where the entire data stream is averaged over, one may wish to use a smaller overlap (or perhaps none at all) when computing a spectrogram, to maintain some statistical independence between individual segments. It is for this reason that the default window is a Tukey window with 1/8th of a window's length overlap at each end.
is a string or tuple, it is passed to
to generate the window values, which are DFT-even by default. See
for a list of windows and required parameters. If
is array_like it will be used directly as the window and its length must be nperseg. Defaults to a Tukey window with shape parameter of 0.25.

data.type_: str or tuple or array_like, optional

data.value: Length of each segment. Defaults to None, but if window is str or tuple, is set to 256, and if window is array_like, is set to the length of the window.
Number of points to overlap between segments. If
Length of the FFT used, if a zero padded FFT is desired. If
Specifies how to detrend each segment. If
is a string, it is passed as the
function. If it is a function, it takes a segment and returns a detrended segment. If
, no detrending is done. Defaults to 'constant'.
, return a one-sided spectrum for real data. If
return a two-sided spectrum. Defaults to
, but for complex data, a two-sided spectrum is always returned.
Selects between computing the power spectral density ('density') where
has units of V**2/Hz and computing the power spectrum ('spectrum') where
is measured in Hz. Defaults to 'density'.
Axis along which the spectrogram is computed; the default is over the last axis (i.e.
Defines what kind of return values are expected. Options are ['psd', 'complex', 'magnitude', 'angle', 'phase']. 'complex' is equivalent to the output of
with no padding or boundary extension. 'magnitude' returns the absolute magnitude of the STFT. 'angle' and 'phase' return the complex angle of the STFT, with and without unwrapping, respectively.
Spectrogram of x. By default, the last axis of Sxx corresponds to the segment times.
Compute a spectrogram with consecutive Fourier transforms.
Generate a test signal, a 2 Vrms sine wave whose frequency is slowly modulated around 3kHz, corrupted by white noise of exponentially decreasing magnitude sampled at 10 kHz.
Note, if using output that is not one sided, then use the following:
Lomb-Scargle periodogram for unevenly sampled data
Power spectral density by Welch's method.
Cross spectral density by Welch's method.

signature.value: spectrogram(x, fs=1.0, window=('tukey', 0.25), nperseg=None, noverlap=None, nfft=None, detrend='constant', return_onesided=True, scaling='density', axis=-1, mode='psd')
